description.plain:
Led by frontman Dan Reynolds, Imagine Dragons is an American alt-rock band that originated in Las Vegas. While the band began in 2008, the group boasted an entirely different roster than most are familiar. Before releasing their debut album, Night Visions in 2012, the band released six EPs over four years, constantly shifting their sound and roster from folk to the crowd-shattering anthems they’ve been known for since.

The band’s roster was finalized before Night Visions‘ release with Daniel Platzman on the drums, Wayne Sermon on guitar, and Ben McKee on bass. Their break-out single, “Radioactive” was essential to putting Vegas on the map musically, citing The Killers before them. The song went on to becoming an international success, shattering the record for the most weeks on the Billboard Hot 100 at 87 straight weeks.

It wasn’t until 2015 the band released their sophomore album, Smoke + Mirrors. The album was extremely deviant from their freshman album, characterized by an accentuation of their Rock roots and an internal struggle, later described by Reynolds as his bout with severe depression.

After a self-imposed hiatus in 2016, the band premiered their third album, Evolve, during Super Bowl LI. As the title suggests, Evolve was seen as another evolution of the band’s sound, with a newfound focus around Pop and EDM. It only took a year for the band to release their fourth full-length album, Origins, characterized as a sister album to Evolve.

description.plain:
“Believer” thunders around a percussive backbeat and expressive vocals from Dan Reynolds to bring about a message of embracing pain, and using it as a tool for personal growth. It marks the end of Imagine Dragons' self-imposed hiatus that started in 2016. The song acts as the title for their documentary surrounding LGBT youth and the Mormon church.

The song was released on the first of February as the lead single for their third studio album, Evolve, and was featured in a commercial for the Nintendo Switch that premiered on Super Bowl LI. The song was also featured in the first trailer for Kenneth Branagh’s Murder on the Orient Express remake.

Nearly two years after its release, the band released a remix of the song alongside Lil Wayne during their 2019 National College Football Championship halftime performance.

songs.recording_location: Wolf Cousins Studios (Stockholm, Sweden) and Ragged Insomnia Studio (Las Vagas, NV)

description.plain:
“Thunder” is the second single from Imagine Dragons' third album, following “Believer”.

“Thunder” is about not conforming to society’s standards. Dan sings about being told what to do as a child, and that he can’t follow his dreams. In the second verse, he says that he overcame everyone that told him what to do, and achieved his dreams of being on stage.

“Thunder” peaked at #4 on Billboard’s Hot 100, and scored the band their first song to surpass 1,000,000,000 (one billion) views on YouTube.

description.plain:
While the fast-paced verses of “Whatever it Takes” propels Imagine Dragons into new territory, the big and booming chorus retains a sense of their signature sound.

The song is about being the best at what you do no matter the obstacle, a theme found to be prevalent on the album.

The song was released as the first promotional single from EVOLVE after official singles, “Believer” and “Thunder.”

description.plain:
“Demons” is the fourth single from Imagine Dragons' debut album, Night Visions, and the lead track for the band’s Demons (Remixes) – EP. The track is about acknowledging and battling your insecurities and inner flaws, characterized as your “demons.”

“Demons” marks the band’s second track to chart for over a year, following the incredible success of “Radioactive.” This song was also used as the theme song for the 2015 Chinese film, Jiu ceng yao ta (Chronicles of the Ghostly Tribe).

description.plain:
The first song on Imagine Dragons' debut album Night Visions gives off a revolutionary vibe, but leaves what is being changed up to interpretation. Some argue it is about nuclear war, others say it is about Wall Street and similar protests, and some think it is really talking about the end of the world. Regardless, it is a powerful song bound to inspire debate on its meaning.

Peep the remix ft. Kendrick Lamar.

Or the Syncronize remix

description.plain:
“Natural” is Imagine Dragons‘ third single after the release of Evolve, following their collaboration with Kygo on “Born to Be Yours”; it is the lead single for their fourth studio album, Origins. The single’s artwork features the same artist from Evolve, Beeple.

According to Dan Reynolds, the song is about becoming a little ruthless and calloused with time as you realize you have to fight and stand up for yourself. This song became the anthem for 2018’s ESPN College Football season and was even featured as Amazon Music’s and Shazam’s Song of the Day.

songs.recording_location: Wolf Cousins Studios, Stockholm & Ragged Insomnia Studio, Las Vegas

description.plain:
“Not Today” is a ballad about how love has the power to emerge victorious against seemingly insurmountable obstacles. It’s the lead single off the soundtrack to the film Me Before You, and the lyrics seem to reflect the plot. In the movie—based on the 2012 Jojo Moyes novel of the same name—a wealthy business man, Will,  is paralyzed in a motorcycle accident. At the height of his despair, a woman named Louisa becomes his caretaker, giving him a new outlook on life.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eh993__rOxA

description.plain:
Touching on the topic of the tough year lead singer Dan Reynolds and his wife Aja Volkman had following their announcement of their divorce on April 26, 2018, “Bad Liar” is the fourth single from Imagine Dragons‘ fourth studio album Origins. The track was released the day the pair announced they hadn’t actually signed the divorce papers and were dating once again and were back together again, just days before the release of Origins.

“Bad Liar” is solely about Dan Reynold’s marriage, and the frontman recruited his ex to help him out with the song, as explained in an interview taking place shortly before it was released, making Aja Volkman a co-writer.

description.plain:
“Next To Me” is Dan Reynold’s romantic anthem to his wife, Aja Volkman. The song describes Reynold’s “frailties” and problems/fears with commitment. He confesses he has never truly written a “love song,” especially one so pensive, due to his harsh histories with love in the past. Dan explains, “it sounds like a cliché, but love conquers all.”

The single’s sonicality and musicality is mirrored through a waltz timing which climaxes during the drop in the Bridge, furthering the passionate lyrics.

Alongside its debut, Imagine Dragons unveiled their Evolve World Tour and “new things to come” on their Instagram. The tour is planned to be accompanied by AGT winner, Grace VanderWaal.

description.plain:
“Walking the Wire” possesses the signature Imagine Dragons bass-heavy, meaningful, pulse racing sound. The track is about overcoming hardships and struggles in a rocky relationship. Knowing that they can succeed means they can get higher up.

The track was released as the second and last promotional single in preparation for the release of their album Evolve.

description.plain:
Imagine Dragons' breakthrough hit, “It’s Time” hit #15 on the Billboard Hot 100 despite being an alternative/indie song. As Dan Reynolds croons about “giving the commodities a rain check”, an infectious mandolin riff backs the song up.

In an interview, lead singer Dan Reynolds explained:

‘It’s Time’ is a song I wrote at a low point in my life. It started as a poem then I turned it into a melody and recorded it on my computer. It was a song for myself to cope with the low points of life – I was dropping out of college at the time. To hear it on the radio is a bit baffling.

songs.recording_location: Studio at the Palms Casino Resort (Paradise, NV)

description.plain:
“Zero” is a song by Imagine Dragons for the film, Ralph Breaks the Internet. The song acts as the lead track from the film’s soundtrack alongside songs by Daft Punk and ​will.i.am, among others. The song also acts as the second track released in preparation for their fourth studio album, Origins.

Under a joyful and upbeat facade, the song speaks of the hardships and struggles one has faced since his or her early days. It reminisces over the thought that they are never enough for anyone and won’t amount to anything. Subtle references of suicide and depression are found throughout the entirety of the song.

While the song first mysteriously surfaced as a Spotify ad days before its release, “Zero” officially premiered as Zane Lowe’s World Record on 19 September, 2018.

songs.recording_location: Rodeo Recording, Santa Monica & Ragged Insomnia Studio, Las Vegas

body.plain:
“Zero” is a song by Imagine Dragons for the film, Ralph Breaks the Internet. The song acts as the lead track from the film’s soundtrack alongside songs by Daft Punk and ​will.i.am, among others. The song also acts as the second track released in preparation for their fourth studio album, Origins.

Under a joyful and upbeat facade, the song speaks of the hardships and struggles one has faced since his or her early days. It reminisces over the thought that they are never enough for anyone and won’t amount to anything. Subtle references of suicide and depression are found throughout the entirety of the song.

While the song first mysteriously surfaced as a Spotify ad days before its release, “Zero” officially premiered as Zane Lowe’s World Record on 19 September, 2018.

description.plain:
“Rise Up” is the fifth track from Imagine Dragons' third studio album, Evolve.  The song is sandwiched between two genuine and soft-spoken songs, which intensifies the powerful, strained vocals in the chorus.

In essence, the song talks about rising up to face all of your troubles, dealing with themes regarding empowerment, hope, and success.

At the end of the Evolve Summer Tour in Berlin, the song was used as a tribute to the late Mac Miller who had passed two days prior.

songs.recording_location: Rodeo Recording (Santa Monica, CA) and Rugged Insomnia Studio (Las Vegas, NV)

description.plain:
“On Top of the World” is an uplifting track from Imagine Dragons‘ debut album, Night Visions. The track first appeared on their seventh EP, Continued Silence. On both albums, “On Top of the World” was preceded by “Demons.” Over a year later, the band released the song as a single on March 3, 2013.

While the song sold well on itself, the track was featured commercially for The Croods, Coca-Cola, FIFA, and Ford among others.

Perhaps its most prestigious use was performed by the PS22 children’s choir as the opening to President Barack Obama’s 2013 Inauguration.

description.plain:
“Warriors” is a song written and recorded by American alt-rockers Imagine Dragons.

The band wrote and recorded the song alongside Riot Games for the 2014 League of Legends World Championships. The event is a tournament hosted by Riot Games for high-profile League of Legends, competing to determine the best team in the world.

description.plain:
One of three bonus tracks on the deluxe edition of Origins, “Birds” muses on fading memories and a couple’s gradual parting of ways and promises eternal love, using a metaphor of migrating birds; a natural part of life.

Likely inspired by Dan Reynolds‘ changing relationship with his wife Aja Volkman, Dan insisted they would remain best friends even after their temporary split.

Although not originally a single from the album, the song became a fan favorite, being broadcast on numerous international radio stations and encouraging the creation and release of a remix with Italian singer-songwriter, Elisa.

description.plain:
“Machine” is the third single from Imagine Dragons' fourth studio album Origins. The song was first teased in their trailer for the album and its release date was announced for Halloween on Zane Lowe’s World Record on October 30, 2018 as well as through an Instagram and Twitter post with the song’s cover.

The message of the song is to stop doing what others try to make you do and follow your heart and do what you have to do. The song also possibly delivers a strong political message to vote for the right person during the upcoming US elections on November 6, 2018.

description.plain:
“I’m So Sorry” is the fourth track on Imagine Dragons‘ second studio album, Smoke + Mirrors. Arguably one of the heaviest tracks the band has ever made, in competition with fellow Smoke + Mirrors track, “Friction”, “I’m So Sorry” is embroidered in a lyrical tango that seems to depict two sides of a man in limbo over love.

One interpretation of the song could be that he had wronged his step father, by lying his way through life. The song could be about how he realizes his mistakes, and works to fix the wrongs he has done. While different interpretations can come out from the lyrics, one thing’s to be agreed on: the music itself is fanatically heavy, with the band channeling their love for rock as a genre in this track.

description.plain:
“I Bet My Life” is the fifth track on Imagine Dragons‘ second studio album, Smoke + Mirrors. A return to the band’s more soulful music, the track is a song about apology and forgiveness. One of many Imagine Dragons songs about human relationships, the song is written from the perspective of a man reflecting on past mistakes.

Inspired by Dan Reynolds' relationship with his own parents, the song’s subject wishes to live the rest of his life with the person that he had neglected the most; he realizes they were showing him the right path all along.

body.plain:
Led by frontman Dan Reynolds, Imagine Dragons is an American alt-rock band that originated in Las Vegas. While the band began in 2008, the group boasted an entirely different roster than most are familiar. Before releasing their debut album, Night Visions in 2012, the band released six EPs over four years, constantly shifting their sound and roster from folk to the crowd-shattering anthems they’ve been known for since.

The band’s roster was finalized before Night Visions‘ release with Daniel Platzman on the drums, Wayne Sermon on guitar, and Ben McKee on bass. Their break-out single, “Radioactive” was essential to putting Vegas on the map musically, citing The Killers before them. The song went on to becoming an international success, shattering the record for the most weeks on the Billboard Hot 100 at 87 straight weeks.

It wasn’t until 2015 the band released their sophomore album, Smoke + Mirrors. The album was extremely deviant from their freshman album, characterized by an accentuation of their Rock roots and an internal struggle, later described by Reynolds as his bout with severe depression.

After a self-imposed hiatus in 2016, the band premiered their third album, Evolve, during Super Bowl LI. As the title suggests, Evolve was seen as another evolution of the band’s sound, with a newfound focus around Pop and EDM. It only took a year for the band to release their fourth full-length album, Origins, characterized as a sister album to Evolve.
